div1.p: Carter is available to meet with Frost at any time and states that she and Brown continue to try to find incomplete bibliographical references.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, March 14, 1929
div1.opener:
Book, Bibliography
Frost
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
March 14, 1929.
Dr. Wade H. Frost,
School of Hygiene and Public Health,
615 North Wolfe Street,
Baltimore, Maryland.
Dear Jack:
div1.p:
Your very kind letter of March 13th., has just reached me.
I deeply appreciate your congratulations on my having finished the
revision of the bibliographic cards. Personally, I am thankful, rather
than glad (would have been both had not my many physical set-backs so
delayed things).

It will be entirely agreeable to me to over to Baltimore next week, at
any time you name, and for as long as you wish, to help you get in
order all the bibliographic material needed in the final revision in
editing Father's MS. Indeed, it will be a privelege, as well as a
deep gratification, if I can be of any assistance to you in this, or
any other detail of the work, to which you are contributing so much
that no one but yourself or Father could give.

Re the bibliographic cards, I assume that you realize that even
now, despite unremitting work, we can't report a “100% batting average.”
Indeed, your previously-quoted “law of diminishing returns” comes morer mever more
in evidence! Some references simply cannot be found and some have had
to be considerably revised. In the latter cases, the data on which such
revision has been (tentatively) made, have been copied for you in order
that you may pass final judgment. There has been, and will be, far more
work for both you and myself in connection with the bibliography than I
had anticipated. This I am sure you realize from the cards you have al-
ready seen, which will already also have helped to demonstrate how ne-
ne-
-2-
cessary it was to do this work thoroughly.

Its an unspeakable comfort to realize that, with you again “taking
the helm,” the book, as Father wished it, should soon be an accomplished
fact. Surely it has lain heavy on my soul!

With much love to “the Susans” and more gratitude to yourself
than I can express,

closer.seg:
P. S. Miss Brown and I are still “camping on the trail” of the
remaining incomplete references. Got two verbatim quotations (from Las
Casas) last night) by style and context, Father not having mentioned the
author. Indeed, one could go on working indefinitely, were time not a
factor, on so extensive and diversified a bibliography, to which it al-
ways seems possible to add something of simplification or elucidation.
Still, I consider it well worked up, and, as I wrote you last Sunday,
“we” will report to you for duty at any time you designate.
L. A. C.
